awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kimberly Ann Klinger Logan is "Intersections of Number Theory and String Theory: Differential equations in automorphic forms applied to zeros of L-functions and graviton scattering." The host institution for the fellowship is Rutgers University and the sponsoring scientist is Stephen D. Miller.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The projects supported by this grant inform the connection between number theory and particle physics by investigating eigenvalue problems involving automorphic forms. This is done by studying Poisson type differential equations involving automorphic forms. Differential equations of this form appear both in problems involving zeros of L-functions as well as in computations of graviton scattering arising from string theory.  These differential equations can be expressed using ODEs involving special functions that cannot be solved by traditional methods. In fact, solutions have yet to be found in all cases and even those we do know cannot be written down concisely. 


In work with Miller and Radchenko, and separately with Fedosova, the PI found solutions to a family of differential equations (which generalize the one which appears in the graviton scattering amplitude) both directly and using Python. With these authors, we formally verified, and later generalized and proved, a conjecture coming from physics which gives an exact identity for a shifted convolution of divisor sums. This work gives a family of identities which express convolution sums of even divisor functions in terms of Fourier coefficients of Hecke eigenforms. Since these specific identities are related to the homogeneous solutions of the desired PDE, they yield information about the graviton scattering amplitude and imply that a different basis should be used in such computations (as well as in certain computations related to N=4 SYM theory). Furthermore, convolution sums of divisor functions have been studied since Jacobi and arise in computations of subconvexity bounds and moments of L-functions.


With Chandee and Li, this grant also supported work which relates the pair correlation of low-lying zeros of GL(2) L-functions to eigenvalues for random matrices. As a consequence, assuming GRH, we obtain that more than 93% of the low-lying zeros of Γ1(q) L-functions are simple. Along this theme, with Thalgoda and Wong, we give special values of a new Dirichlet series. Other work with Wong in this area gives an extension of an important result of Goldfeld and Sarnak to the Bianchi setting. This is an important tool used throughout number theory. In our case, this result gives the equidistribution of the certain elliptic Dedekind sums. Further, with Bianco Prado, the PI found operator equations satisfied by the Hurwitz zeta function. 


In terms of broader impacts, the PI mentored many students at various stages of their academic careers. She, along with Blankers, Kobin, DeVleming, and Roy, co-organized a regular themed lunch panel series called “Lunch in the Time of Covid” which served as a social and mentoring opportunity for graduate students and early career mathematicians. The PI was also involved with K-State’s Sonia Kovalevsky Day (an event consisting of Math Circle type activities for middle schoolers aimed at getting young girls excited about STEM) and the Navajo Math Circle. In the summers of 2022 and 2023, the PI went to Page, AZ to run math activities for the 2-week math camp for middle and high school Navajo students.
